comments.body:
A possible way to handle this would be to fetch the bitstream info from DataSpace via the API and then download the files via cURL. The API provides the name of the file and even an MD5 to check for integrity. 

Here is a proof of concept Ruby script to create a Bash script to download the files for a given collection: https://gist.github.com/hectorcorrea/d1b5e4f9d3a1de4a68114a194b0804f4

```
$ ruby ruby getbitstreams.rb > get1061.sh
$ chmod u+x get1061.sh
$ ./get1061.sh
```

Since the files will be downloaded to a folder named after the handle of the DataSpace item, these folders could be uploaded to Globus via the Globus Connect Personal.

comments.body: Rebased and force-pushed today.

The test failure is in the bibdata role, which is complaining that:
```
TASK [switch to Ruby "ruby2.6" release for the system default] *****************
  fatal: [instance]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "msg": "no command given", "rc": 256}
```

The failing task currently reads:
```
- name: switch to Ruby "{{ ruby_version }}" release for the system default
  ansible.builtin.command: ruby-switch --set "{{ ruby_version }}"
  changed_when: false
```

The root of the problem may be that the `ruby-switch` package has disappeared or is hard to find: https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/ruby-switch. Can we use a different approach to setting the system default ruby?
we are currently on 7.88, but should upgrade to 7.89
